principles: Responding to partner's emotional needs by acknowledging bids (Principle of Bid Responsiveness).
Continuous effort and commitment are essential for maintaining a healthy relationship (Principle of Relational Investment).
Effective communication is fundamental to relationship satisfaction and longevity (Principle of Communicative Effectiveness).
rules: Partners must actively 'turn toward' their partner's emotional bids at least 86% of the time (Bid Responsiveness Rule).
Schedule and maintain regular one-on-one time together (Minimum Weekly Contact Rule).
Schedule and maintain regular shared rituals (Ritual Scheduling Rule).
Schedule and maintain specific special activities (Special Activity Scheduling Rule).
Acknowledge and accommodate partner's needs for solo time (Solo Time Accommodation Rule).
Follow specific strategies to handle stress and provide support during stressful times (Stress Management Protocol).
Specifically address conflict using strategies to avoid the Four Horsemen (Conflict Resolution Rule).
Maintain a specific approach to friends and family (Friendship/Family Integration Rule).
claims: Adherence to bid responsiveness rules significantly increases relationship trust, passion, and satisfaction.
Consistent scheduling of one-on-one time and shared rituals strengthens the relationship.
Regularly acknowledging and meeting partner's needs for solo time enhances well-being and relationship quality.
Following specific stress management protocols leads to better coping and relationship outcomes.
Successfully avoiding the Four Horsemen prevents relationship deterioration and breakup.
Commitment to specific principles and rules leads to a fulfilling and lasting relationship.
warnings: Failure to respond appropriately to emotional bids can lead to misunderstandings, resentment, and decreased relationship satisfaction.

Failure to maintain scheduled rituals may result in a lack of shared experiences and connection.
Neglecting special activities can diminish shared joy and commitment.
Inadequate attention to solo time needs can cause stress and conflict.
Ineffective stress management can impact individual well-being and relationship dynamics.
